ygData.subject: Re: Role/Anon/norm
ygData.msgSnippet: All this makes me just not want to be a Druid! I often just walk up to folks and say hello, but the begging for SoWs or other stuff has jaded them so much that
ygData.messageBody:
All this makes me just not want to be a Druid! I
often just walk up to folks and say hello, but the
begging for SoWs or other stuff has jaded them so much
that they often say, "Sorry, I'm not a Druid." Fine, I
was just trying to say hello. I rarely ask for SoW
(although I love to have it when hiding/sneaking), but for
the rare occasions when I do, I've actually hotkeyed
a social RP request. "I am on a mission from my
guild masters . . . Would you be so kind as to bestow
Spirit of Wolf on me, if you could?" It comes out as a
couple of lines, but that's OK. <br><br>Two funny things
happened in the last couple of days, sort of germane to
this discussion. Last night, I died in Crushbone and
had to run back all nekkid. I got a bit twisted
around, and had to ask directions. Watched politely (and
not hidden) as some big Barb killed a centurion, then
said, "Excuse me, which direction is the entrance to
Crushbone?" And he walked away to go kill some more stuff.
Hmph. I wandered around a bit more, getting my bearings
. . . and came across him fighting three or four
centurions. And for all his nice shiny armor (a major
twink,perhaps?!), they stomped this Barb into the ground. I was
hiding/sneaking, and it was sort of fun to watch. Felt like adding
a comment like "Be polite next time and you might
get some help!", but I refrained.<br><br>But this one
from two nights ago is better . . . even though it's a
long story. Whenever I go to Kelethin, when I see a
fellow Dwarf I tend to stop and say hello. I kind of
dislike the place (very high platforms, and it's very
confusing), and it's nice to see a friendly face. So I saw a
Dwarf and said hello, and we got to talking. <br><br>I
noticed a Wood Elf nearby with the same surname, and
asked if that was his partner. He said yes, they had
met while adventuring, etc. She SoWed me and they
cast a couple of other buffs on me. I told him he was
a lucky Dwarf . . . "She has a sister, you know!" I
demurred, saying I wouldn't want to impose the life of a
Rogue on anyone (and besides, my real-life wife would
have a cow). So the Wood Elf Druid mentioned the name
of her sister . . . and I realized I had adventured
with her! We hooked up once in Butcherblock to kill a
Fire Drake, and she later suggested we meet the next
day. She had some scarab armor she wanted to give me.
<br><br>The server had died the next night, however, so we
never got together again. Her sister then said, "Wait
here, she asked me to give you something if I ever met
you." So she ran to the bank and came back with a some
Scarab boots and a Splitpaw Belt -- both were marked
improvements over what I had on. It was great -- meeting
someone in character, having a conversation, getting some
buffs and some items just for being in the moment.
<br><br>That's what makes this game great.<br><br>Of course,
then the newbie who had been bugging me all night for
items or gold showed up, asking me to show her (a him,
really) who to give the bard letters to. Said s/he had a
20-something level warrior on another server . . . and here
s/he is, begging for items as a first-level HE
magician. Couldn't even get the dang letter from the bard
in Felwithe -- I had to tell her to answer with the
words in brackets!<br><br>That's what makes the game
not so fun sometimes, although it was good to help
someone.<br><br>Gee, maybe I should do some work today . . .
<br><br>Kharlisht of Kaladim<br>11th season rogue<br>Drinal
